The new Dune film has brought visions I thought could only exist in the mind. Denis' intense passion for this story shines through in every scene. Dune truly sets a new precedent for science fiction in film and as a lifelong Dune fan, I can't wait to see what the future holds.
Dune is stunning but it‚Äôs not just about the spectacle - the performances are so heartfelt and urgent. In particular, Timoth√©e Chalamet and Rebecca Ferguson are fantastic.

DUNE does manage to satisfy the stratospheric hype. Despite feeling like the starter in a three course meal, it skilfully balance it‚Äôs visuals and storytelling as well as it‚Äôs intricate characters. This is without a doubt Timoth√©e Chalamet‚Äôs most captivating role yet #Venezia78
#Dune is astonishing. Heartbreakingly beautiful, layered, meaningful and epic. On paper it‚Äôs absolutely not my thing. On screen it absolutely is.

#Dune is properly epic and a true blockbuster. The type we haven't seen since Lord of the Rings. The kind of movie that no home theatre setup could do true justice. With genuine stakes and a satisfying lack of superheroics. And Hans Zimmer's best score.

#Dune is fantastic and thrilling and provocative and strangely timely, too. Got my political brain working and my sci-fi bone going too. Really enjoyed it and I'm praying they're able to finish the story with a sequel. #Venezia78

I left DUNE shaking. This is how people seeing 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY back in 1968 for the first time must have felt. The grandeur of this thing is off the charts. However blown away you think you‚Äôre going to be, multiply it by ten. #Venezia78

DUNE (2021). It‚Äôs a cosmic mix, the action of the 90s combined with the exploitation films of the 70s, but with modern touches. It's hyperviolent, but it knows what it is. It's a little bit Tarantino. It's definitely a little bit Michael Mann. It's kind of a cosmic gumbo.

On one level, DUNE is a Mainstream novel, read by far more than Science Fiction readers. It's usually thought of as SF, but rare for SF, it is not dependent on technology; it's about people. It's also Fantasy. How do you categorize this great novel? Maybe it can't be categorized.

It occurs to me now that the real reason Frank Herbert banned computers in the Dune universe is because of all the difficult computer science issues that crop up when you mix prescience with cache invalidation algorithms.
